import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react'; import { Header, Icon, Segment, Grid, Modal, Button, Embed, Image, Rating, Divider } from 'semantic-ui-react'; import _HeaderMovieCast from './_HeaderMovieCast'; import ReactPlayer from 'react-player' const _HeaderMovieDetails = ({url}) => { const [open, setOpen] = useState(false); const [dimmer, setDimmer] = useState(''); const show = (dimmer) => { setDimmer(dimmer); setOpen(true); } const close = () => { setOpen(false); } console.log(url) return ( show('blurring')}> Play } dimmer={dimmer} open={open} onClose={() => close()}>
Narcos
Narcos: Mexico is the story of Mexico’s first drug kingpin, Miguel Ángel Félix Gallardo (Diego Luna). The 10 episodes that premiere this week detail the dramatic implosion of Gallardo’s empire, a collapse that makes for extremely bingeable television. Yet, despite the thrilling spectacle, exhaustion seeps in. Even though it aims at being something more, Narcos: Mexico doesn’t seem to have ambitions far beyond those of the criminals it follows, pushing more product. ) } export default _HeaderMovieDetails;
